prompt.p: An overweight 40-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of worsening lethargy. She says that she constantly feels tired and cold, despite a healthy diet and no major changes in lifestyle. She also complains of hair thinning and menorrhagia. She is medically fit and does not take any medications.
Examination reveals coarse facial features with rough and dry skin. Her hair is dry and brittle, and the outer third of her eyebrows has also thinned. Reflexes are sluggish.

modalFeedback.p: Option E is Correct. The history suggests a presentation of hypothyroidism, which can be diagnosed by requesting thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 levels.
Option A is Incorrect. Abdominal X-ray will not assist the diagnosis here; the patient has not presented with gastrointestinal symptoms.
Option B is Incorrect. Although anaemia may explain the patient's tiredness, this does not cause coarse facial features or sluggish reflexes.

Option C is Incorrect. Whilst this investigation would be helpful in identifying menopause or polycystic ovarian syndrome, there is no suggestion of either of those two diagnoses in this presentation.
Option D is Incorrect. There are no suggestions of Cushing's or Conn's syndrome and cortisol will therefore not be as useful as thyroid function tests in the first instance.
